text.p: Reducing transport emissions, in particular CO2 emissions from passenger vehicles, is a key element in mitigating the risk of climate change. Conventional welfare economics recommends the use of comprehensive pricing of carbon emissions, which may not necessarily be the most effective approach in transport systems. This paper uses an evolutionary technology diffusion model to simulate the impact of climate policies on passenger car emissions in the US, UK, Japan, China and India up to 2050, seeking to understand policy interaction. We analyse six commonly seen policy instruments and explore systematically the impact of combining each of these policies by developing 63 scenarios for the US, UK, China, Japan, and India. We assess both the policies' effectiveness in achieving emissions reductions and their cost-effectiveness in doing so. We show how the diffusion dynamics of the system can lead to interaction of policy levers, generating synergies in some cases (combined effectiveness more than the sum of its parts), and mutual impediment effects in others (combined effectiveness less than the sum of its parts). The paper identifies particular combinations of regulatory, procurement and fiscal policies that are particularly effective at generating rapid change without needing the use of very high fuel taxes or carbon pricing. Notably, combining electric vehicle mandates with taxes and regulations on combustion vehicles is highly effective, as it simultaneously improves the availability of low-carbon options while penalising high carbon options. Simple principles for policymaking can be inferred.

The transport sector is the third greatest contributing sector to global carbon emissions [1] and was responsible for over 24% of energy-related carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions in 2016. In particular, the passenger light-duty vehicle (PLDV) fleet is projected to expand from 900 million in 2012 to 1.7 billion in 2035 [2]. The rapid diffusion of electric vehicles (EVs) and improvements in the cost-effectiveness of non-electric car fleets is important in limiting energy demand growth by curbing oil use and limiting greenhouse (GHG) emissions [3,4].

Understanding a suitable stringency and the structure of public policies is necessary to influence the adoption of new car technologies. Human-technology systems (or socio-technical regimes) possess inertia and display resistance to change, which makes them durable for multiple social, economic and technical reasons [5]. The transition to low emissions vehicle fleets may require diverse policy instruments that allow existing technologies in niches to diffuse into the market. The design, level, and structure of the instruments determine the effectiveness of the policies in achieving long-term emissions targets. In policy practice, diverse types of policies are almost always introduced simultaneously, aiming to control different types of externalities (e.g. fuel use, road use, emissions). These incentives likely interact in ways not always fully understood, providing price and regulatory signals for purchase decisions and use behaviours, thereby compounding their effect on the transition to low-emission vehicles.

The impacts of the policies are typically heterogeneous across countries and time, and can be non-linear, partly due to the inherent high heterogeneity of markets [6]. Some consumer markets are less likely to adopt low-emission technology until a certain critical mass is reached. Particular combinations of policies could be more effective in overcoming technological lockins and decarbonising private transport than others. This must be understood when designing new frameworks aiming at rapid decarbonisation.

Many studies consider one policy in isolation (e.g. [7,8]). Of the studies exploring policy packages, most have looked at the integrated impact of policy mixes in achieving deep CO2 emissions reductions [9][10][11]. Although a few studies have examined the interaction of policies [12][13][14], these studies predominantly have investigated the impact of policy interactions in the US and Canada.

However, no studies have comparatively explored interaction effects between policies across multiple countries. Similarly, none have examined whether the same insights hold between developed nations (e.g. the US, the UK, Japan) and large, emerging economies (e.g. China, India) with high-demand growth. Thus, insights offered by recent research have remained tied to national contexts, and are difficult to translate.

In the transport literature, significant consideration has been given to the synergies and tradeoffs between policies [15]. There are trade-off (or reinforcement) effects between two policies if the presence of two policies offers a smaller (or larger) CO2 mitigation benefit than the sum of the effectiveness of either policy alone. This study aims to quantify the trade-offs and synergies that exist between policies for mitigating CO2 emissions from passenger cars in the five major economies: the US, the UK, China, India and Japan. These countries have been chosen for this study because their vehicle markets possess very different characteristics, which are the results of different histories of policies and regulations, and they also constitute a major component of the global car fleet [6]. This comparative study enables us to examine how the structures of different car markets influence the levels of policy stringencies necessary to induce transitions in current passenger car systems. In this paper, the higher the policy stringency, the higher the cost of the policy for the consumers (taxes) and the government (EV subsidy). In the same manner, the more stringent the EV mandate, the more ambitious the EV target sales. We discuss possible options available to policymakers to minimize trade-off effects and maximize synergies in policy design. In pursuit of these objectives, this paper addresses the following questions:

1) Can an evolutionary model of vehicle fleets predict and explain trade-off or reinforcement effects between any existing types of policy instruments on the diffusion of PLDVs in each of the five countries? How significant are the trade-off and reinforcement effects on overall incentives?
2) How do the trade-off and reinforcement effects between policy instruments affect the costs and efficiencies of the policy combinations, and can this be used to guide policy design?

To answer these questions, we performed scenario analysis using the FTT:Transport model, an evolutionary technology diffusion model for road transport technology, as a submodule of the Integrated Assessment Model (IAM) named E3ME-FTT-GENIE (see [9]). The Future Technology Transformations (FTT) family of models consists of FTT:Power [16], FTT:Transport [9], FTT:Heat [17] and FTT:Steel [18]. The purpose of the design of the FTT models is to simulate the evolution of fleets through technology diffusion dynamics that follow standard theory on the diffusion of innovations [19]. The model makes use of coupled S-shaped curve (non-equilibrium) dynamics, driven by agent decisions, following preferences, decision rules and perceived incentives, calibrated to reproduce observed technology trajectories. The FTT models use a modified evolutionary version of discrete choice theory in which social influence is integrated [20]. Its strong path-dependence and high policy resolution allow explicit assessment of policy interactions, with a modelling horizon of 2050. The paper is structured in comparative form, and aims to unearth general principles for low-carbon policymaking that are context-independent in path-dependent transport systems.

The algorithm used is based on a simulation of dynamical systems, as opposed to the systems optimization frequently used in technology models. The FTT models enable modelling of technological diversity, heterogeneous consumer decision-making and the complex evolving interactions between policies. The FTT:Transport model offers a highly detailed set of policy packages, and allows the modelling of different transition pathways that then lead to different future technology scenarios [9].

The remaining paper is structured in the following manner: Section 2 provides a literature review of previous research on the analysis of policies. Section 3 discusses existing policies for encouraging low emission vehicles in the five major economies. Section 4 describes the model and methodology used to perform the scenario analysis. Section 5 details the variables and data sources used in this study. Section 6 provides the assumptions for the scenario analysis. Section 7 presents the results of this scenario analysis and discusses their policy implications. Section 8 offers insights for policymakers, and finally, section 9 provides a conclusion.

The scenarios most often assessed by the IPCC have primarily focused on harmonised carbon pricing/taxing as a policy strategy [21]. Focusing on transport, other studies have analysed the mid-to long-term impacts of various individual policy instruments on the CO2 emissions from the PLDV sector using quantitative models [8,13,[23][24][25][26][27][28][29]. Most studies have only examined the impacts of various taxes on long term CO 2 emissions. For instance, Kloess et al. [24] investigated the effect of various tax incentives and technological progress on the Austrian passenger car fleet. Using the UK Transport model, Brand et al. [30] assessed the long-term scenario of several low-carbon fiscal policies, such as vehicle purchase taxes, road taxes and scrappage programs, as well as their effects on CO 2 emissions from the PLDVs.

The zero-emission vehicle (ZEV) mandates have existed only in the US and some regions of Canada. Sykes and Axsen [13] examined the impact of the ZEV mandate on the long term sales in North America using CIMS-ZEV. Karplus et al. [8] studied the cost and effectiveness of fuel economy standards, alone and in conjunction with economy-wide policies constraining GHG emissions. Small [31] assessed the cost and effectiveness of fuel tax, vehicle efficiency standards, and financial subsidies on CO2 emissions reduction from passenger light-duty vehicles in the US with the National Energy Modelling System (NEMS). Morrow et al. [23] analysed fuel taxes, continued increases in fuel economy standards, and purchased tax credits for new vehicle purchases, as well as the impact of combining these policies to reduce GHG emissions and oil consumption in the US transportation sector. Outside North America, studies have only analysed the impacts of various financial incentives on developed countries. Thus, as discussed above, many studies on policy instrument analysis have focused on studying the impact of one instrument on a particular country [25,32,33]. However, individual policy instruments have limited effectiveness or must be unrealistically stringent, whereas the combination of instruments can be more effective. In fact, a more integrated policy mix of strong policies is required for deep GHG emissions [34]. Even when studies consider the impact of several policy instruments, they tend to focus on the collective impact of the policy instruments on CO 2 emissions [10,23,29], while ignoring the interactions among the policy instruments on the emissions of PLDVs. Despite the prevalence of policy mixes in many nations and regions [35], very little transportation research has studied policy interactions, particularly for policy mixes for light-duty vehicles [15]. While it is important to examine the overall impact of a group of policies, the interactions among the policy instruments are central to any policy mix because of their collective influence on the effectiveness and costeffectiveness of instruments in the mix, and thus the design of the policy strategy [19,36,37].

When systems are path-dependent, and various policies are combined, they can be either mutually reinforcing or work against one another, depending on how they are designed and implemented [38]. For example, policies focusing on improving vehicle choice availability (technology push) can reinforce the impact of policies influencing pricing (technology pull) [39]. In other words, there can be synergies or interference effects between instruments, and it is thus important to understand the effects of policy interactions. The design of an effective policy package requires an understanding of policy interactions [34]. Several studies have discussed the possible impacts of policy synergies and policy mixes on the effectiveness and the impacts of policies regarding emissions reductions in the energy sector [13,34,36,37]. However, few studies go beyond qualitative statements. An exception is a study by Viguié and Hallegatte [42], which provides a multicriteria analysis on the trade-off and synergies of various urban climate policies, such as zoning and public transport subsidies. Elsewhere, Fischer and Fox [43] carried out scenario analysis on carbon taxes and rebates for mitigating carbon leakage. More specific to light-duty vehicles, Axsen and Wolinetz [44] simulated the impact of incentives and mandate-based strategy on plug-in EV sales in Canada. Jenn et al. [12] examined the individual and combined effect of light-duty vehicle GHG emission standards and the Zero Emissions Vehicle policy in the US. Thus, we identify two main gaps in existing studies for the analysis of policy instruments on long-term CO2 emissions. First, existing studies, as we have illustrated, have focused on studying policies for only one country or region. Although this approach is useful in understanding the impact of policies on a certain country, it does not allow for the inference of impact for other countries, or explain why or under what conditions the policies would be effective and be cost-efficient. Second, many existing studies have been ex-post policy evaluation studies. None of these studies examine the interactions between multiple policies within the PLDV sector using a dynamic model. A comparative study of policy interactions across several countries with different characteristics is required to provide insights into policy actions in passenger road transport.

The levels and designs of incentives vary greatly across our case study countries. This section summarises the main policy objectives and policies that have been implemented in the UK, the US, Japan, China, and India to encourage the diffusion of low-emission vehicles.

The UK has adopted a target of net-zero emissions for 2050, which includes transport [45]. The EU first established a law requiring new cars registered in the EU to emit no more than an average of 130 grams of CO 2 per kilometre (gCO 2 /km) by 2015. By 2021, the average fleet target for new cars is 95 grams of CO 2 per kilometre. From 2021 onwards, assuming some minimum degree of regulatory alignment with the EU for transport, the average emissions of all newly registered cars of a manufacturer must be below that target [46]. Vehicle Excise Duty (VED), also commonly known as vehicle road tax, is an annual tax levied on vehicles using public roads. Typically, it is levied on the basis of vehicle characteristics, such as engine size, weight, or power. More recently, the CO 2 -graded VED was recalibrated with higher band resolution and slightly higher duties [30]. In addition to the exemption from the VED, in the UK, the electric car (plug-in car) grant is intended to incentivise electric car purchases by offering 4,500 GBP toward the purchase of an electric car (plug-in car) on a zeroemission range of at least 70 miles [45].

The transport sector has surpassed the power sector as the single largest US emitter of GHGs for the first time since 2016. Following the US withdrawal from the Paris Agreement, 24 states formed the US Climate Alliance and will uphold the original US commitment, reducing emissions 26% to 28% below 2005 levels by 2025 [47]. This could change again if the US rejoins the Paris Agreement.

Since 2011, the federal government has offered an income tax credit to owners of fuel-efficient vehicles, ranging from $2,500 to $7,500 per vehicle, based on each vehicle's traction, battery capacity and gross vehicle weight rating [48].

The Energy Tax Act of 1978 requires car companies to pay a 'Gas Guzzler' tax on the sale of cars (excluding light trucks and SUVs) with exceptionally low fuel economy. Under the Obama Administration's standards, the auto industry was required to double the fuel economy of vehicles to an average of approximately 54 miles per gallon by 2050. However, more recently, under the Trump administration, the EPA has been considering freezing the fuel-efficiency targets at 2020 levels [49].

Many states and local governments offer a wide variety of incentives beyond what the federal government requires. These incentives take many forms, including rebates, income tax credits, sales tax exemptions, and fee exemptions. Among all the non-fiscal policies that have an obvious bias towards NEVs, the zero-emission vehicle (ZEV) credit mandate in California is the most representative incentive. It sets minimum sale percentages of ZEVs and credits to be given to the manufacturers based on vehicle type and all-electric range [50,51].

Japan has pledged a 26% emissions reduction in GHG below 2013 levels by 2030, including the transport sector [52]. In 1998, Japan initiated the Top Runner Approach, which has set mandatory efficiency standards for automobiles based on the most efficient products. By 2015, the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry (METI) announced that the new standard to be achieved by passenger cars was 12.7-23.5 km/L. If these numerical targets in the new standards are successfully achieved, fuel efficiency in the target fiscal year (FY) of 2022 will improve by 26.1% from the actual level in FY2012 [53].

There are nine different taxes for owning cars in Japan, including acquisition tax, consumption tax, tonnage tax, automobile tax, gasoline tax, diesel tax, LPG tax, and in-use consumption tax [54]Zero-emissions vehicles are exempt from both the acquisition and the tonnage tax. The owners of cars that are compliant with the 2015 FES enjoy up to an 80% reduction in acquisition tax, and a 75% reduction in automobile tonnage tax [54].

Under the Paris Agreement, China committed itself to reach peak carbon emissions around 2030. More recently, President Xi announced a net-zero emissions target for 2060, thus current policy regimes are likely to change. Meanwhile, the transport sector has become one of China's fastest-growing economic sectors [55]. At the national level, to reduce its dependency on foreign oil and to encourage more fuel-efficient vehicle technologies, the passenger vehicle market has been subject to fuel economy standards since 2004. The Chinese government also provides direct subsidies for the purchase of EVs at both central and local levels. According to the driving mileage of vehicles, the EV purchaser can receive up to RMB 55,000 (USD 8,000) in subsidies from the central government. However, in 2019, China's Ministry of Finance announced its plan to reduce by half subsidies for EVs sold in the country with driving ranges of 400 or more kilometres to RMB 250,000 (USD 3,600) [56]. Beyond this, many local governments provide additional subsidies. For example, in Shenzhen, Guangzhou and Beijing, owners of certain EVs (with ranges above 250km) can receive subsidies of up to RMB 110,000 (USD 17,000). EVs are also exempt from various taxes and regulations, such as purchase tax, license lottery (in Beijing and Guangzhou), and toll charges [57]. The New-Energy Vehicle Credit Program was finalized in September 2017 and was implemented in 2018. Under the NEV credit program, car manufacturers with over 30,000 annual vehicle sales in the country are required to produce 10% NEVs in 2019 and 12% in 2020 [58]. Companies that do not reach their quotas will face fines, but they could buy credits from manufacturers having a surplus.

India's NDC sets a target for reducing emissions by 33% to 35% between 2005 and 2030. The transport sector is a key area for meeting this goal [59]. To promote eco-friendly vehicles, in 2015, the Indian government launched the FAME (Faster Adoption and Manufacturing of Hybrid and Electric vehicles) measure to incentivise HEV and EV purchases. Under FAME India, the Indian government will provide incentives from Rs. 138,000 (USD 2,000) for every electric car sold [60]. In addition to subsidies for new energy technologies, excise duties are levied depending on the sizes, engine types, and whether the vehicles are new energy technology vehicles. For EVs, India has reduced the excise duty from 8% for conventional cars, to 4% for EVs [61]. In addition, individual states have their own incentives for energy-efficient vehicles. The Government of India set the first fuel economy standards for the nation in 2014. This standard set a fleet target of 130gCO2/km, which came into effect in 2017. It proposed that the standard could tighten to 113gCO2/km by 2022 [62].

The Future Technology Transformation (FTT) model is a loose framework method that models technological diffusion dynamically, based on technological competition in markets. The FTT:Transport model assumes the presence of an adaptive, evolving, path-dependent market with heterogeneous agents. We assume revealed preferences, in that the observed cost distribution for recent vehicle sales corresponds to the heterogeneity of consumer preferences and choices (see [6,9] for details).

The FTT framework models technological diffusion by a set of logistic differential equations of the Lotka-Volterra family, which represent gradual technological substitution processes [16]. Under the FTT framework, consumers are more likely to choose a technology that has a higher market share as a result of availability, visibility, social influence and network effects, all of which we represent combined simply as adoptions proportional to current market shares (see Equation 1). It is well established that these bandwagon effects substantially influence the profiles of diffusion of vehicle models [63,64]. As shown in Appendix B.6, if one adds bandwagon effects such as social influence in a discrete choice model, one obtains a Lotka-Volterra (replicator dynamics) evolutionary system that generates S-shaped curves [20]. Financial incentives such as EV subsidies, road tax and fuel tax have been adopted by all of the countries in this study (i.e. the UK, the US, Japan, China and India). Besides financial incentives, fuel economy standards require automakers to design more efficient vehicles or to shift sales toward more efficient models. To boost the population of zero emissions vehicles, a cap-and-trade EV mandate has been introduced in some states in the US (e.g. California) and China, and this has the potential to rapidly scale EV manufacturing and adoption [51,65]. For that reason, all of these policy types must be represented in all of the countries in the model. In this paper, policy formulations take six possible forms: vehicle tax, annual registration tax, EV subsidy, fuel tax, EV mandate, and fuel economy standards.

In the FTT model, each layer of policy plays a specific role in the decarbonisation of the transport sector. When the policies are simultaneously simulated in the model, they influence the each other's effectiveness. For example, taxing high-emission vehicles with a vehicle tax will encourage consumers to purchase low-emission vehicles. In a consumer market with limited EV models available, a consumer will be more likely to choose a lower-emission petrol car, due to the path-dependent nature of the model (Equation 1). However, in the presence of the EV mandate, manufacturers are encouraged to produce more EVs and to offer more options to consumers. The higher EV shares in the FTT model lead to a higher rate of diffusion for EV, considering the S-shaped technological diffusion curve (Equation 1). Hence, policy interactions emerge endogenously in the FTT:Transport model. With different current market shares and cost distributions (see Appendix B.5.1, Fig. B3) for different countries, consumers respond to policies differently across different markets.

For the present study, an extensive original database detailing the technological profile of cars and populations was built. The 2016 data for new registration per vehicle model type were obtained from MarkLines [66] and matched to recent prices and car specifications, extracted from the official websites of the manufacturers. Data gathering for FTT:Transport is described in detail in [9].
The data sources and key parameters for the FTT:Transport model are presented in Appendix A.1 (Table A1) and Appendix A.2 (Table A3-A7), respectively.

In this study, policies are first tested individually, and then we combine the policies to assess the interactions between policies. The scenarios are modelled to demonstrate the impact of individual policies and combinations of policies on CO2 emissions until 2050. The analysis consists of 63 scenarios, including all possible policy combinations of six commonly seen policies for five countries. Table 1 provides an overview of these scenarios. Policy assumptions for the scenarios are presented in Table 2. Under individual policy scenarios, policy measures that have already been implemented will continue to be used in the future with the same dynamics, but with increased stringency. In this paper, policy stringency is defined as a higher price of CO2 mitigation. For taxes, a higher price per unit of CO2 implies higher stringency. A higher subsidy is interpreted as more stringent than a lower subsidy. Larger improvements in fuel efficiency for new cars imply more stringent fuel economy regulations. In addition, an EV mandate is more stringent when the government sets a higher EV sales target.

Assuming that policies will become more stringent in the future, financial incentives will be 50% higher than those of the current policies in individual countries. 6 We assume that passenger car owners/operators would pay a registration fee/vehicle tax based on engine size or their emissions, consistent with existing policies around the world. Zero emission vehicles such as EVs will be exempt from paying car acquisition taxes (VT) until 2050. The amount of EV subsidies depends on battery size and EV ranges. We assume that EV subsidies would be phased out by 2040.

Following the proposals by the EU and US, in the 'fuel economy regulation scenario', we assume that current inefficient petrol cars and diesel cars would be phased out in 2025, replaced by more advanced models featuring additional innovations designed to reduce energy use and emissions. Beyond this, we assume that the fuel economy for the advanced petrol and diesel cars is 30% higher than that of the current petrol cars in the UK, and 20% higher than that in the US. Since the long-term fuel economy standards (up to 2030) for Japan, China and India have not yet been recorded/published, we used adopted fuel economy standards in our analysis. Hence, in the 'fuel economy regulation scenario', we assume that current petrol and diesel cars in China, India, and Japan would be phased out by 2030. Instead, they would be replaced by advanced petrol and diesel cars that will be 35% more efficient than the current petrol cars in China, and 20% more efficient than those in Japan and India, as shown in Table 2.

Since the EV mandate is absent in the UK, India and Japan, we assume that these would be introduced and that their stringencies would be the same for other countries such as China, for scenario analysis purposes. Under the EV mandate scenario, we assume that 10% of new car sales are EV, consistent with the level China proposed beginning in the year 2019. For the purpose of scenario analysis, we assume that the level of EV mandates would remain constant until 2050. We acknowledge that EV mandates could become more stringent over time. Thus, a more stringent scenario is tested and demonstrated in Appendix G. Notably, in the FTT:Transport model, the initial diffusion of EVs will lead to further EV diffusion. This implies that EV mandates can be removed after a certain sales threshold is reached.

This section analyses the effectiveness of individual policies when these incentives are introduced independently (without interactions) for different countries. Tables 3 and4 show the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of individual policies.

Among financial incentives, the annual registration tax is the most effective in all the countries. This is because the total cost of the annual registration tax is among the highest of all policies. For example, in the US, the annual registration tax is USD 600 per year under the high registration tax scenario. For buyers that hold on to their cars for 10 years, this amounts to USD 6,000 over the lifetime of a car.

Comparatively, the effectiveness of financial incentives is the lowest in India. This is because the shares for EVs and hybrid cars are still minimal in India. When the shares for new energy technologies are small, the rate of diffusion is low because many people do not have access to EVs or an EV infrastructure and perhaps do not trust EVs (e.g. range anxiety). In such a situation, financial incentives affect only a very small subset of all vehicle owners.

Among the five countries studied, the EV subsidy is the most effective in China, leading to 420 MtCO2 cumulative emissions reductions. In contrast, the diffusion of EVs as a result of EV subsidies has a minimal effect on the total emissions in the PLDV sector in India and Japan. In India, this is because the shares for EVs are very small (less than 0.1%) despite the presence of EV subsidies, which is the lowest among all of the countries. Similarly, while the shares for EVs are higher in Japan than India, the shares for EVs (in the car fleet) in Japan were still below 0.3% in 2018, and 1% in 2019 in China. The lower the market shares are for the technologies, the larger the lock-in effect is in the FTT model, and the lower the rate of technological diffusion is.

As shown in Table 3, cumulative emissions are reduced by more than 1000 MtCO2 in India. In fact, we find that the EV mandate is the most cost-effective policy in reducing emissions and encouraging the diffusion of EVs in all countries. This finding contradicts the economic theory that taxes (or technology-neutral policies) are more costeffective than technology-specific strategies [67], such as the EV mandate. We argue that in the presence of market and infrastructure failure within the transport sector, without technologically specific policies, consumer choices could not be incentivised collectively by an externality price.

Our results differ from the findings of Fox et al. [68] that tax scenario is more cost-effective than technology-specific standards such as EV mandates. These differences stem from the strong path-dependence structure in the FTT:Transport model. In the present study, we assume that the EV mandate has a plateau, instead of becoming more stringent over time (as assumed by Fox et al. [68]). In the FTT:Transport model, once the EV reaches a certain market share, the technology will take off without more stringent EV mandates.

Under the 'fuel economy scenario assumptions', advanced petrol and advanced diesel cars penetrate the market, replacing conventional petrol cars and diesel cars. Among the US, Japan, and India, we find that the fuel economy regulation is more effective in the US. This is because there are a large number of luxury petrol cars (i.e. engine size 2000cc and above, such as SUVs) in the baseline scenario in the US. Thus, we find that as a result of the 'fuel economy scenario assumptions', cumulative emissions fall by more than 2000 MtCO2 in the US.

In this section, we study how the effectiveness of policies changes when two policies are combined. Overall, we find that the sum of the effectiveness of two policies is generally not equal to the sum of the effectiveness of policies applied individually, but it could be either smaller (trade-off effect) or larger (reinforcement effect) than two policies implemented on their own, depending on the structure and levels of policies (Fig. 2). The cost of each policy combination (Table 6) and the average cost for each policy combination (average efficiencies) are shown in Fig. 3. Thus, we conclude two main observations from the scenario analysis.

First, we generally find a trade-off effect between the various types of financial incentives under this analysis (as shown in the red bars of Fig. 2), whereas the degree of the trade-off effect depends on the stringency of individual policies in each country. This is because financial incentives are charged based on the fuel economy (e.g. fuel tax) or engine size (e.g. annual registration tax). If consumers are incentivised to buy more energy-efficient PLDVs because of one of the incentives, the 'additional effectiveness' of adding more financial incentives will be lower because the costs (of pairing incentives) for consumers of more efficient cars will be less than those for consumers with less efficient cars. For instance, when a car buyer chooses a more efficient vehicle as a result of the annual registration tax, the effectiveness of a fuel tax falls as the fuel economy improves. Hence, we find that in all countries, there is a trade-off effect between annual registration tax, vehicle tax, fuel tax and EV subsidy.

Fig. 3 shows that, in general, the costs of two financial policies in combination are higher than the average cost of two policies. This finding, to some degree, confirms the principle of welfare economics that only one tax should be used at a time to maximise cost-effectiveness. Overall, when the combination of policies is not sufficiently effective, these policies could result in very high costs per ton CO2 emission reduction. For instance, in the case of Japan, the average cost and combination cost of vehicle tax and EV subsidy are both over 6000 USD/ton CO2 emission reduction (Table 5).

In this section, we study the interactions between multiple policy instruments applied simultaneously by adding policies to the existing two-policy mixes and examining the changes in interactions between policies. The objective of this exercise is to understand how the tradeoff and synergetic effects between policy strategies evolve, and the implications of the interactions between multiple policies on policymaking. Here we will focus on three-policy mixes (Tables 7-8 and Fig. 4), as more complex mixes could logically be inferred from these results. We show results for four to six policy mixes in Tables E1-E6 in Appendix E.

As shown in Fig. 4, in most cases, the effectiveness of three policies combinations (the grey bars) are higher than two policy combinations. When three policies are combined, consistent with two policy combinations, trade-offs originate from combining multiple financial policies, while synergies arise from combining policies with the 'enabling' EV mandates, multiplying their impact.

The overall trade-off effects of three policy combinations are larger than those trade-off effects of two policy combinations, due to the accumulation of trade-off effects between pairs of policies. However, we observe that the overall trade-off effects of three policy combinations are smaller than the sum of the trade-off effects of individual pairs. The explanation for this finding is that the additional financial incentive (e.g. EV subsidy) increases the shares for low emissions vehicles (e.g. EVs) slightly, and this encourages more people to purchase EVs with the same policy combinations improves the effectiveness of the policy package. Hence, the cost of three policy combinations is smaller than the average cost of individual pairs, as shown in Table 7. It is more cost-effective to combine three financial incentives than pairing financial incentives. This result is contrary to what is predicted by welfare economics, that there are more penalties the more instruments are used. In the FTT:Transport model, due to the interactions between policies, the introduction of another layer of policy could improve the overall effectiveness of the 'policy package', and thereby improve the cost-effectiveness of the original policy combination.

Similarly, in the cases of four-and five-policy combinations, in the absence of an EV mandate, we observe that while the overall trade-off effects increase with the number of policies, the overall trade-off effects are smaller than the sum of the trade-off effects of individual pairs. For example, the trade-off effects between fuel tax, EV subsidies, vehicle tax, and fuel economy standards are smaller than the trade-off effect when the registration tax is added to the policy package for all of the countries (Tables E1 andE3 of Appendix E). This is because in the FTT model, due to path dependency (see Equation 1), when the shares for EV are very low (as assumed in most countries), and the original policy package (four policy package) does not lead to significant change in the diffusion pathway, addition policies such as annual registration tax offers limited benefits for significantly reducing emissions.

This research sought to promote a better understanding of the interactions between existing policies for policymakers in five major economies. We simulate scenarios for various incentive measures already implemented, and examine the interactions between policies by analyzing both trade-off and reinforcement effects between any pair of policy instruments and multiple policies. We created 63 scenarios, consisting of all possible policy combinations of the six commonly seen policies for five countries.

Overall, we find that there are trade-off effects between all types of financial incentives because such incentives are charged based on the fuel economy (e.g. fuel tax) or engine size (e.g. annual registration tax). This implies that the outcomes of each policy combination are not merely additive. If consumers are incentivised to buy more energy-efficient vehicles due to one of the financial incentives, then the effectiveness of the paired incentives will be lower because the total cost (of taxation) imposed on consumers buying more efficient cars is smaller than the taxation imposed on consumers buying less efficient cars. Hence, the existence of one incentive weakens the overall financial incentives of another policy.

Policymakers should consider the trade-off effects, which weaken the overall effectiveness of the policy combinations. More stringent financial incentives have to be introduced to compensate for the trade-off effects of financial incentives. Our analyses on the interactions of multiple policies reveal that the overall trade-off effects of multiple policy combinations are smaller than the sum of the trade-off effects of individual pairs and that the effectiveness improves as more financial instruments are added to the existing policy mix. However, this may prove more costly as cost-effectiveness falls when more financial incentives are added.
The results suggest there might be a trade-off between policy effectiveness and costeffectiveness of adding financial incentives.

On the other hand, there are reinforcement effects between the EV mandate and all of the other policies. Since the EV adoption rate increases with higher starting EV shares, the EV mandate magnifies the impact of the other policies. When there are more EVs available, there are more choices for consumers, which improves the effectiveness of taxes on emissions in comparison with situations presenting fewer choices.

We determine that while the EV mandate is not always the most effective policy to significantly cut emissions when introduced on its own, there are substantial reinforcement effects between an EV mandate and financial incentives (e.g. fuel tax, EV subsidy, annual registration tax). Therefore, it is more cost-effective to introduce financial incentives with the EV mandate. We find that in the analyses of multiple policy combinations, the presence of an EV mandate in policy mixes substantially reduces the cost of emission reductions. However, with an EV mandate, we find that overall reinforcement effects fall as more financial policies are added to the policy mixes. This suggests that a stronger EV mandate is required when more financial incentives are introduced to mitigate the trade-off effects (see Appendix G). As the number of EVs on the road increases, it will be possible to achieve further emissions reduction as a result of the existing financial incentives.

The non-linearity in a policy mix permits building policy combinations that lead to more effective outcomes than a set of policies developed independently. The appropriate number and selection of policies are dependent upon the prevailing economic conditions and the current structure of the automobile market in individual countries. Table 9 presents key findings regarding the effects of policies are introduced in isolation and in combination with other policies. Generally, we find that policy combinations achieve the highest reinforcement effect when an EV mandate is combined with fuel economy regulation. Certain car market conditions, such as the number of EVs on-road and stringencies of existing policies, are major influences on the choice of policies. Hence, in the UK and the US, we find that the reinforcement effect is the highest when an EV mandate is combined with fuel economy regulation, EV subsidies and registration taxes. In China, on the other hand, where the annual registration tax is relatively lower than in the US and the UK, the reinforcement effect is the highest when an EV mandate is combined with fuel economy regulations and fuel tax. In countries such as Japan, where current car fleets are already more fuel-efficient than other countries in this study, we find that the most effective combination emerges when fuel economy regulation is combined with EV mandates and an EV subsidy.

The existence of synergistic effects contradicts basic principles of standard welfare environmental economics, which assumes that policies do not interact positively. The standard theory, which has considerable influence on present-day structuring of policies, states that the use of one instrument per externality should be used, and that more instruments would lead to inefficiencies. In our context here, this would mean observing only trade-offs. We do observe this, but only in a very limited number of cases. Due to path-dependence in transport systems, we find that the combination of policies of different natures and structures work most efficiently. For example, while a single fiscal instrument such as a tax on fuel would have to be unrealistically high to achieve emissions targets. However, in combination with other types of instruments -such as fuel economy regulations and EV mandates -such a tax could be substantially lower and produce the same outcome at a much lower cost to both public budgets and consumers

General principles for road passenger transport policymaking, true for all markets, that can be inferred from this work are that one has to (1) create or enhance the availability of zero-carbon vehicles, inorder to enhance the effectiveness of other policies, and (2) tax and/or regulate out the purchase and/or use of high carbon vehicles to disincentivise their presence on roads. If either of those things is not done, the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of policies, irrespective of what they are, are much lower than they could otherwise be. (3) Layering policies (adding policies to existing policies) without careful evaluation could be ineffective and cost inefficient due to policy interactions.

Following that, policymakers must choose whether they prioritise effectiveness or costeffectiveness (cost over rapidity of emissions reductions). When synergies arise, lower stringency policies can be used to achieve goals; when interference arises, higher stringency has to be used to achieve goals. This can guide the choice of policymakers for the composition of policy packages, in which financial incentives generally tend to interfere with one another, whereas financial and non-financial policies tend to synergise. Across countries, fuel economy regulation that phases out less fuel-efficient cars is the most effective policy when introduced in countries with many large, conventional cars (e.g. the US). We find that policy synergies seem to be lower in Japan, where there are a number of hybrid cars in the baseline scenario. In the FTT:Transport model, the incumbent technologies have a distinct advantage and cause technological lock-in. Achieving a significant long-term CO2 emissions objective becomes more difficult with the same policy and stringency in the presence of technological lock-in. Hence, an EV mandate is a useful policy to kick-start the diffusion of EVs in countries where the shares for EVs are low.

Notably, in this study, we assume that policies are introduced simultaneously when the shares for EVs are low. Further studies should look into the timing of the policies on the overall interactions between policies. Beyond these general rules, the model must be used with tailored scenarios to explore specific policy questions. We conclude that policy interactions are a very important topic to study, and that more systematic research should be conducted on this subject.

Limitations exist in the current methodology and projections. We assume that consumer demand induces the diffusion of technology in the private passenger car transport sector and that automakers are treated exogenously.

In this research, we find that an EV mandate is the most cost-effective policy. This is partly because we assume that the cost of an EV mandate to consumers is the difference between the prices of EVs and conventional cars (see Appendix D.5). Over time, consumers could potentially 'gain' from EV purchases if the prices of EVs were to fall below the prices of conventional cars due to technological learning. In reality, policies such as EV mandates set annual EV credit targets instead of sales targets, as assumed in this paper. We have not taken into consideration the cost of EV mandates on the manufacturers or the government. For instance, to facilitate the implementation of EV mandates or EV subsidies, governments and manufacturers often need to invest in the construction of EV-charging infrastructure, and this has not been considered here. Hence, we acknowledge that the cost consideration for EV mandate may be simplified.

Transport demand is driven by income, population, urban density, family structure and other demographic factors. Studies have also found induced and rebound effects on the demand for passenger car transport. More specifically, they find that the demand for transport increases with economic and infrastructure development. For example, the enhancement of road capacity in the US and Britain positively impacts transport demand. Improvements in the infrastructure, such as highway development, generate new consumption of fossil fuels and CO 2 emissions, known as the induced effect. Improvements in energy efficiency in vehicles may lead to an increase in the service demand for PLDVs, and thus, offset the efficiency gains from technological diffusion, known as the rebound effect. Hence, it is important to consider the elasticity of demand for transport in relation to fuel price, energy efficiency, and road accessibility in the estimation and projection for the demand for PLDV services.

The demand estimation in this section consists of two parts. The first part is the construction of an econometric model that predicts the demand for PLDVs (in km per vehicle) using fuel prices, income, urbanisation, road infrastructure, urban density, and fuel economy. Then we use the econometric model to predict the future private passenger vehicle transport demand (per vehicle). In the second part, we develop a model for vehicle stock and project future car ownership, which is then used to make projections for the total demand for PLDVs.

The empirical model specifies kilometres per PLDV in the country i as a function of GDP per capita (Y), fuel cost in terms of oil price (FP), and a group of variables, including urbanization (U), road lengths (M), urban density (UD), and fuel economy (FE). We estimate the dynamic model because efficiency improvements and fuel price changes take time, and static models may not capture adequately the long-run adjustments of transport demand. The dynamic model we specify captures the historical trend of passenger vehicle travel demand.
The interpretation for each variable is indicated in Table B1. The following section summarises the rationale for each variable in Equation B.1.

Income is known to drive transport demand, and it is recognised as the main driver of transport demand growth per capita income since higher incomes allow individuals to spend more on travel. Studies have found that, while there exists a positive correlation between income and transport demand, the income elasticity for transport demand may decline as a country becomes richer [91].

Since fuel prices affect fuel costs' share of the total cost of driving, we expect that a fall in fuel prices will increase the transport distance due to the rebound effect. A large number of studies have examined the elasticities of gasoline prices in transport fuel demand [92,93]. Price elasticities are almost always negative: an increase in price leads to lower demand, and vice versa.
Interpretation and units of indicators.
Urbanization rate is defined as the share of the urban population to the total population [85].

With the gradual increase in the proportion of the population living in urban areas and higher urbanisation rates, over half of all people were living in urban areas by 2012 [94]. With a higher urbanisation level and as a result of agglomeration economies, it becomes easier for people to access shops and restaurants. As urbanisation progresses, cities become more congested, making it is less convenient to use private cars. With improved public transportation and better accessibility to all aspects of urban life, the average distance travelled by cars declines [91,95].

Travel distances are often shorter in cities that have greater density due to congestion and the presence of public transport networks. A number of studies have found that travel demand decreases with increased urban density. Karathodorou et al. found that there is a negative relationship between passenger car fuel consumption and urban density [64].

The relationship between accessibility to destinations and the demand for transport can be measured as an induced effect. In both the UK and the US, Nolan and Lem [95] concluded that the expansion in road capacity has a positive impact on traffic demand. In the case of China, Chai et al. [96] found that when road accessibility (measured in mileage) is increased by 1%, road traffic demand increases by 1.26%.

As fuel economy improves, the average fuel cost per km falls, and the demand for passenger transport increases as a result of the income effect. The rebound effect is expressed as the percentage of the forecasted reduction in energy use that is lost due to consumer and market responses [97].

The results for the pooled OLS estimates are presented in Table B2. A country dummy variable is added to account for the unobserved effect. With the Breusch-Pagan test, we analyze whether it is valid to pool the data. The null hypothesis H0 for the Breusch-Pagan test is that the variance of the unobserved fixed effects is zero (i.e., it is possible to use the pooled OLS model). As the test results show, we fail to reject the null hypothesis, meaning that the random effects regression is not appropriate. This implies that a pooled OLS model is superior to the randomeffects model.

As Table B2 shows, the adjusted R-squared indicates that the model has strong explanatory power (R-sq=0.89). Consistent with existing studies, the results show that oil prices, urbanisation, road mileage, population density, and fuel efficiency have a significant effect on road transport demand. Income does not significantly affect the distances travelled by car per year probably because, as income increases, people purchase more vehicles instead of travelling more in each car. The coefficient results show that road accessibility has a positive effect on road transport demand, while travel demand decreases by 1.5% when the oil price increases by 10%. As countries become more urbanised, people take advantage of the public infrastructure when they are in cities. Hence, we find that distance per car falls as countries become more urbanised and that distance per car increases as more roads are built (induced demand). Fuel efficiency improvements will result in a transport increase, although the effect is small (travel demand increases by 0.3% when fuel efficiency improves by 10%).

The problem with the pooled OLS model is that the outcome variable (travel demand) depends on explanatory variables, which are not observable but are correlated with the observed explanatory variables. We conduct the Hausman test to validate the suitability of the fixed effects (FE) Model. For the static models, we hypothesise that the best model is the FE model and test this with the Hausman test. Table B2 shows that fixed effects should be used since the chi-square test statistic is 35.02 and has a p-value of 0.00. Hence, we dismiss the Random Effects Model. However, only three variables are significant in explaining the variability in the transport demand. Consistent with the findings in the OLS regression, we find that oil prices and urbanisation decrease travel demand, while population density increases travel demand. The total significance of the model is not very strong, with an R 2 of 0.45. There are two main reasons for this. Firstly, unlike what is observed in the OLS model, the FE model removes the non-observable fixed effects. Secondly, there is a significant trend in the time series, which can be captured only with a dynamic panel model.

To account for the dynamic effect in the panel data, we use the Arellano-Bond estimator with the general method of moments (GMM), which includes the lagged dependent variable as one of the explanatory variables. For dynamic specification, the GMM estimator of Arellano and Bond, which is estimated in the first differences with instruments in levels, is required to remove the unobservable individual-specific effects. The Arellano-Bond estimator controls the fixed effects by first-differencing and assuming that the idiosyncratic error is serially uncorrelated. We carry out the regressions with the GMM in one step with robust standard errors. Table B2 shows the results for the GMM regressions. All variables are significant at either the 5% or 10% levels. Note that the signs for the coefficients of the variables in the GMM estimations are consistent with the OLS pooled estimation and the FE model. In order to validate the assumptions of the Arellano-Bond GMM estimator, we carry out the Sargan test, which yields a result of 145 with a p-value of 0.6308. Hence, we cannot reject the null hypothesis of over-identified restrictions.

B.5.1 Heterogeneity in the vehicle market Consumers in vehicle markets are highly heterogeneous, and this heterogeneity varies by country. Sales for new passenger cars were obtained from MarkLines and matched to price and fuel consumption information from car manufacturers. Note that MarkLines data are comprehensive, not samples. Fig. B3 (also see [6]) shows an example of price heterogeneity in five countries, the US, UK, China, Japan, and India in 2012. For this paper, we have updated the cost distribution to 2016. We observe that the heterogeneity of vehicle markets varies widely between nations.

In consumer behaviour theory, consumers are most likely to make purchases according to their own experiences with the technology or to the consumption experiences of their peers gained through social interaction [103] and visual influence (demonstrated by [63] in the US). It is also likely that the choices of consumers are influenced by their peers through the 'bandwagon effect' [33]. The cost distributions reflect the diversity of consumers in terms of choices, taste, and income. The diversity of sales in terms of cost distribution reflects the diversity of agents [6]. We postulate here that distributions of perceived costs correspond to distributions of observed costs, with a possible constant offset between them. People, we assume, when considering purchasing a vehicle, most likely choose something they have seen being purchased, perhaps by someone they know, such that they were able to gather information (i.e., they most likely do not choose something they know nothing of, and they gather reliable information predominantly through observations of their peers). Their observations of the fleet are a subset of what is on roads, and every agent observes something slightly different. This may be due to their belonging to a particular social group and social class, and they are most likely to choose amongst what their peers have previously chosen, which itself is a subset of what the whole market has to offer (e.g. poor rural households perhaps purchase different types of vehicles to rich suburban families, which itself is different than single, middle-class persons). Thus, we assume restricted technology/information access. In other words, agents do not choose what they do not know, and they do not know all of the markets. The FTT model uses a modified version of discrete choice theory in the form of an evolutionary theory. It uses observed distributions of costs to represent agent heterogeneity (a form of revealed preferences) (see [6]). Consumer decisions are modelled with chains of binary logits. In discrete choice theory [104,105], choices are made in a probabilistic fashion, which means that unobserved factors, such as taste variation and interpersonal heterogeneity, are taken into account in the discrete choice model. In the binary logit model, decision making uses pairwise comparisons of cost distributions, as shown in Fig. B4. As inferred from the price distribution of sales, transport costs are not the only factors that consumers consider when purchasing a vehicle. Many additional aspects (e.g. comfort and luxury) are valued by the consumer, of which we have little information beyond the price distribution of what is purchased. We keep in mind that technologies have different pecuniary costs, particularly across engine size classes; despite this, higher costs appear compensated by higher benefits, such that higher cost luxury vehicles maintain market shares. Were we to simulate technology diffusion based on bare LCOT distribution comparisons, the lowest LCOT technologies would diffuse more successfully, which is not consistent with our historical data. Clearly, components would be missing in the LCOT-for instance, comfort, acceleration, and style-which we may call the "intangibles". We define "intangibles" for this model as the difference between the generalized cost, which leads to observed diffusion, and the LCOT, as calculated from pecuniary vehicle properties for which we have data. The interpretation of the g # parameters is that they ensure that FTT projects in the future a diffusion trajectory (the rate of change of shares) that is the same as what is observed in historical data, and represents all costs not explicitly specified as perceived by agents.

The unique set of g # cannot be obtained by simple optimization, as too many spurious local solutions arise. Thus, we need to adjust the values for g # until the sum of the differences between the projected shares and the historical shares for all technologies is minimized. In the case that other capital costs remain unchanged, g # is independent of scenario assumptions and is a constant value, i.e., it only has to be found once. Furthermore, if the definition of the LCOT is changed for any reason (e.g., adding a pecuniary parameter, or changing the discount rate), the empirical g # must all be re-determined since their meaning also changes. In this section, we carry out a sensitivity analysis over most relevant technological parameters of FTT:Transport, including the discount rate, the learning rate, the γ factor (or the "intangible"), and fuel prices. These parameters were chosen because they would generate the most changes in emissions and technological shares. The parameters varied here are as follows:

1. Learning rates for EVs (not varied for conventional petrol and diesel cars because the learning for mature technologies is insignificant). 2. Consumer discount rates. 3. The price of electric vehicles. 4. γi values for all vehicle types. 5. Fuel prices. The variation used is between 5% and 20%, depending on the parameters (see Table F1). The uncertainty range was chosen based on existing literature for the discount rate, learning rate or variations that we consider as reasonable, such as the γi values). Learning rate variations were considered based on [75,106]. We assume a low EV learning rate scenario (5%) and a high EV learning rate (15%) scenario. Following [73], we test a low discount rate scenario (5%) and a high consumer discount rate scenario (25%). The intangibles (g values) are derived from the historical trends of technological diffusion. However, the fitting of g are only accurate to a certain extent, which we estimate between 5% and 20%, depending on the availability of historical data. For instance, EVs have less historical data than petrol cars. In the sensitivity analysis, we vary the g values by 10% for every car technology in order to explore the effect of uncertainties in g values on the final projections. In principle, g values are constants derived from historical data; we do not expect large uncertainties with the g values. Varying the g values too much (i.e., above 10%) would violate the model. For example, if we vary the g values by 30%, then we will find that the diffusion trajectory is no longer consistent (see Appendix B.5.4.1 for more details). The fluctuations of oil prices have a significant effect on the efficiency of cars purchased by consumers and the distance travelled by cars over time. In the FTT:Transport model, oil prices affect total emissions through the demand equations and through consumer choice over car technologies. We have assumed four oil price scenarios: a very low oil price scenario (50% lower than the 2016 oil price level), a low oil price scenario (20% lower than the current oil price projections), a high oil price scenario (20% higher than the current oil price scenario) and a very high oil price scenario (50% higher than the current oil price scenario). Note that it is possible for the oil prices to be higher or lower than 50% of the current oil price projections. The aim of this analysis is to study the effect of a fluctuation in oil prices on the model projections.

It is important to analyse model responses to variations in key parameters to ensure the model is not 'highly sensitive' to very specific values for any particular parameter. As a benchmark, we adopt the definition that a change of X% of CO2 emissions that results from a parameter variation of Y% is 'small' if X is five times smaller Y and 'large' if X is of the order of Y. This is a reasonable definition because if X% change is larger than Y% parameter variation, then we may see a large propagating uncertainty. However, if X% is much smaller than Y%, then the output uncertainty is much smaller than the input uncertainty for each parameter. We conclude this analysis with the following broad findings. Learning rates, EV prices, and discount rates tend to have a small impact on the results (i.e., less than 1% changes in emissions as a result of 5% variation in learning rates and 10% variation in EV prices and discount rates for most countries. The effects of the learning rates on the scenario analysis are the largest in the countries with the highest market shares of EV, such as China, where a 2% decrease in CO2 emissions is the result of a 5% variation (higher) in the learning rates parameter in the baseline scenario. The effect is negligible in the baseline scenario in the countries where there are very few EVs on-road (i.e., India) and where we find that there is no change in emissions as a result of 5% variation in the learning rates parameter in the baseline scenario. For all countries, we find that there is less than 4% change in CO2 emissions as a result of 20% variation in the g value in the baseline scenario. As we have expected, changes in g for one technology mostly affects its own pace of diffusion. Hence, we find that changes in g values have almost no impact on the emissions projections when the shares for EVs are under 1%. Overall, the relatively low impact of varying the g parameters is explained by the fact that the model is not sensitive to small changes in pecuniary cost for individual technologies. Since the model has some degree of momentum and inertia in its diffusion trajectories, changes in the costs data create a change in the trajectory but not an instantaneous change in the shares.
